awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Genomic and Functional Analysis of the Plant Hypersensitive Response
awd_abstract_narration:
Co-PIs Gurmukh (Guri) Johal (Purdue University) and Brian Dilkes (Purdue University)

There are many diseases that can infect crop plants, leading to lower yields and even crop loss.   The ability of crop plants to fight off diseases is therefore a very important agricultural trait.  Farmers can avoid some diseases with pesticides, or breeders can develop crop varieties that resist diseases.  Crops have the ability to fight off diseases by reacting to the disease-causing microorganism with defensive mechanisms, known as the plant hypersensitive response (HR).   This refers to a process whereby an infected cell dies before the infection can spread to other cells in the plant.  Despite its importance to maintain healthy crops, much remains unknown about the HR.  In this work, a multi-disciplinary approach involving a number of field and lab-based techniques will be used to gain a better understanding of the HR in corn, the most economically valuable crop in the US.  The genes and processes involved in controlling the HR will be identified and characterized.  While this work will be performed primarily in corn, it is likely that many features of the HR are shared among different crops.  As such this work will provide fundamental insights into one of the most important ways plants defend themselves against diseases, and the knowledge will be useful to develop improved crop plants by making them more resistant to diseases. Outreach activities with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences will focus on educational activities on genetics, plant breeding, biotechnology and associated societal implications and will build on an existing collaboration with the museum that has developed several instructional modules for middle, high school, home school and mature students and their teachers.  These continuing programs will be supported and several new programs will be developed around DNA sequence analysis, biotechnology and society.

In previous work, a novel genetic screen was used to identify loci, genes and pathways associated with natural genetic variation that controlled HR. In this project, a multi-disciplinary approach involving mutagenesis, field genetics, high-throughput genomic and transcriptomic sequencing, metabolomics, bioinformatics, microscopy and molecular biology will be used to gain an understanding of the HR from molecular genetic, transcriptional, biochemical and histological perspectives.  Genes and pathways controlling the HR response will be identified and characterized.   The HR will be observed at cellular, transcriptional and metabolic levels.  The utility of a novel and potentially widely-applicable approach for the identification and characterization of mutations conferring quantitative phenotypes will be demonstrated. Public access to sequencing data generated this project will be made possible through deposition at the Short Read Archive (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra).  Information on the position of genes controlling the HR at the transcriptional level (expression Quantitative Trait Loci ? eQTL) will be made available at MaizeGDB (maizegdb.org).  Biological materials will be disseminated via the Maize Genetics Coop and germplasm descriptions will be included in MaizeGDB.

por.por_cntn:
The Hypersensitive Response (HR) is a defense response observed in almost all higher plant species.  During HR, cells immediately surrounding the site of pathogen penetration undergo a rapid cell death.  HR is often the most visible component of a set of immune responses known as ?Effector Triggered Immunity? (ETI) which is triggered by the recognition of a pathogen by proteins encoded by plant resistance genes (or R-genes).  ETI often results in almost complete levels of pathogen resistance.

In this project, teams at North Carolina State University (in collaboration with USDA-Agricultural Research Service) and at Purdue University undertook a multifaceted investigation on the HR and other components of ETI.  In particular, they investigated HR triggered by a R-protein called Rp1-D21.  Rp1-D21 is an autoactive mutant R-protein, which means that instead of being triggered by recognition of a pathogen, it is triggered spontaneously and so causes a massive HR.  While Rp1-D21 is therefore extremely debilitating for plant growth, it is useful as an experimental system to study ETI and HR.

Outreach during this project included two teacher workshops run with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences:

1. Educator trek: Using DNA sequence analysis tools in your classroom

This one-day workshop was offered at the museum three times and was taken by more than 30 science teachers from across North Carolina.  Methods of DNA sequence and microbiome analysis were described and discussed. Participants collected environmental samples in their home schools with their students. These samples were sequenced at the museum and, in a subsequent online session, the analysis of these samples was discussed.

2.Educator Trek: Exploring plant genetics

This one-day workshop was offered four times over the life of the grant at the NC State research farm in Clayton NC, and was taken by more than 70 science teachers.  Participants spent the morning in the field with NC State University researchers discussing the techniques they use to search and test for improvements to crop plants. During the classroom portion of the workshop, participants had the opportunity to try out several plant genetics classroom activities. Each participant received a voucher of up to $250 value to purchase supplies for teaching plant biology and/or genetics topics in their classroom.

The activities of ten graduate students, eight post-doctoral researchers and thirteen undergraduate or high school students was fully or partially funded by this grant.

Research fully or partially funded by this grant has resulted (so far) in 38 papers published in refereed journals, including a number of prominent journals in the field and one issued patent.  Highlights of the research include:

1.  Using chimeric plants in which cells carrying Rp1-D21 immediately neighbored cells without a functional Rp1-D21 gene, we demonstrated that the Rp1-D21-triggered HR response is cell autonomous, (i.e. cells require Rp1-D21 to exhibit the Rp1-D21 HR phenotype).  However, some defense signaling aspects of Rp1-D21 activity were not cell autonomous.

2.  The transcriptional and metabolomic responses triggered by both Rp1-D21 and Rp1-D, its wild type (i.e. ?normal?) counterpart were described and were shown to be largely similar.  A gene regulation network was derived.

3. The transcriptional response triggered by Rp1-D21 was shown to be very similar to that triggered by a another autoactive R-protein, indicating that there is likely a signature transcriptional response for ETI.  Regions controlling the transcriptional response (eQTL or expression quantitative trait loci) were defined for the Rp1-D21 response.  All transcriptional data have been deposited in public databases.

4. Rp1-D21 belongs to a class of genes know as Lesion (or Les) genes, which are genes which cause spontaneous patches of cell death (or lesions) on leaves.  During this project, a number of Les genes were cloned and characterized.  Several different classes of Les genes were defined, including some that triggered cell death via the ETI response and others that caused cell death in other ways.

5. A novel and extremely tractable maize seed mutagenesis technique was developed and patented

6. We demonstrated that a conserved protein degradation system was important for regulating the activity of Rp1-D21 and likely other R-proteins.

Many of these findings have implications for our understanding of HR and ETI in plants in general and will ultimately be useful in generating improved varieties with more robust disease resistance.
